description: From Middle English wangere, from Old English wangere (“pillow, bolster”), from Proto-Germanic *wangārijaz, suffixed form of *wangiją (“pillow, cushion”), from Proto-Indo-European *wenǵ- (“neck, cheek”). Cognate with Old High German wangari (“pillow”), Gothic 𐍅𐌰𐌲𐌲𐌰𐍂𐌹 (waggari, “pillow”). Related to Old English wange (“cheek”). More at wang.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A rest or cushion for the cheek; a pillow.

examples: Just as he was about to plunge his wanger into Jonny, Jones arrived.
